text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey, guys.
It's Angel.

Today in the kitchen, I am
cooking up some kung pao
chicken and shrimp.

We are using both chicken
and shrimp in today's recipe.

And this is a classic
Sichuanese dish.

Now, if you've had kung
pao chicken before,

you've likely had the
westernized version
of kung pao chicken.

And the westernized
version usually

doesn't have Sichuan
peppercorns in it.

Now, fun fact--
Sichuan peppercorns

were actually banned from
being imported into the US
up until about 10 years ago.

And that's why the westernized
versions of kung pao chicken
don't use Sichuan peppercorns.

But today, I am using
Sichuan peppercorns

because they are
no longer banned,

and they'll give us this
numbingly spicy heat, which

is a distinctive flavor
of kung pao chicken.

So with that, let's get
started on the ingredients.

First, let's get
our marinade going.

Now, I like kung pao chicken
with half chicken and half
shrimp.

So I've gone ahead to start with
half a pound of chicken thighs
and half a pound of shrimp.

Feel free to change up the
ingredients to whatever you
like to eat.

I know some people
don't like shrimp.
Some people love shrimp.

So I've got best of
both worlds here.

In that same bowl, add one
tablespoon of cornstarch,

one tablespoon of rice wine,
one tablespoon of regular soy
sauce, and half an egg white.
Mix that up really well.

Then set this aside to put
in your fridge for at least
15 minutes.

Now, let's go ahead and prep the
ingredients for the stir fry.

We'll need one tablespoon
of Sichuan peppercorns,

one tablespoon of grated ginger,
one tablespoon of garlic,

five to six stalks of scallions
cut up into one-inch sections.

Now, we're only going to be
using the bottom portions
of the scallions today.

And we'll save a little
bit of the top portion
for some garnish.

Next, two tablespoons
of peanuts-- now,

you can use cashews or
even pine nuts if you want.

But today, I am using
peanuts, because that's

what typically is used in a
classic kung pao chicken dish.

And finally, six to eight
pieces of dried red chillies.

Now, be careful, because not
all chillies are made equal.

Some are way spacier
than the others.

But you'll want to prepare
your chillies by first
taking a wet, damp cloth.

Just lightly wipe
your chillies clean.

Now, you might be tempted to
just rinse these under water.

But please don't, because
water and oil don't mix,

and we will be stir frying
these in hot oil later.
So just give them a good wipe.

And then when you're done,
slice them open in half
with a sharp knife.

Remove the seeds, and
then set them aside.

Next, we'll want to
prepare our sauce.

Start with one
tablespoon of rice wine,

one tablespoon of
dark soy sauce,

two tablespoons of water,
one teaspoon of sugar,

one teaspoon of black
or white vinegar,

and half a teaspoon
of corn starch.

Give the sauce a good
mix, then set this aside,
and we'll start cooking.
Now, let's cook.

Preheat a nonstick pan
or wok on low heat,

and add about three
tablespoons of oil.

Then gently add in your
Sichuan peppercorns,

and cook over low heat to
infuse the oil with the flavors.

After three to five
minutes of sauteing,

remove and discard
the peppercorns,
leaving the oil in the pan.

Next, bring that same pan
up to a medium high heat,

and then add your chicken
and shrimp marinade.

Stir fry for a bit, then add
in your ginger and garlic,

the dried red chilies,
green onions, and peanuts.

Mix and stir fry for
about seven minutes total.

And when the chicken is almost
done, add in your sauce.

Stir well as you
thicken the sauce,
and then stop to taste test.

Check to see if you're
happy with the intensity

of the flavors and
spiciness before adding

any chili flakes or extra salt.
Add more dried chili flakes
if you like for a spicier dish.

Once you're happy
with the spice level,

plate and serve
with a side of rice.

So this is how you make a
classic Sichuan style kung
pao chicken and shrimp.
And it smells amazing right now.
Mmm.
I smell the Sichuan peppercorn.
I can smell the spice.
And I can't wait to try this.

So let's get to the taste
test-- a little bit of chicken,
some green onions for garnish.
That was really good.

I could taste the soy sauce
flavors that [INAUDIBLE]

really well with a
little bit of sweetness,

a little bit of tartness
from the vinegar--

just the right amount
of spice, because we did
do the taste test earlier.
And it's just perfect.

So that is how you
make a classic Sichuan
style kung pao chicken.
I hope you guys like this video.

If you did and you like this
recipe, please give me a
thumbs up.

And don't forget to subscribe
to my channel, Angel Wong's
Kitchen.

And I will see you
guys next time.
Bye.
